text: The Song of Songs, which is Solomon’s.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Let him kiss me with the kisses of his mouth!
    For your love is better than wine.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator
Narrator

text:
I am dark, but still lovely, O daughters of Jerusalem,
    like the tents of Kedar,
    like the curtains of Solomon.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Do not gaze at me, because I am dark,
    because the sun has looked upon me.
My mother’s sons were angry with me;
    they made me the keeper of the vineyards,
    but my own vineyard I have not kept.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Tell me, you whom my soul loves,
    where you pasture your flock,
where you make it lie down at noon;
    for why should I be like one who veils herself by the flocks of your companions?
speaker: Narrator

text:
If you do not know, O fairest among women,
    follow in the tracks of the flock,
and pasture your young goats
    beside the shepherds’ tents.
speaker: Narrator

text: I compare you, my love, to a mare among Pharaoh’s chariots.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Lovely are your cheeks with ornaments,
    your neck with chains of gold.
speaker: Narrator

text:
We will make you ornaments of gold,
    with studs of silver.
speaker: Narrator

text:
While the king was on his couch,
    my nard gave forth its fragrance.
speaker: Narrator

text:
My beloved is to me a bundle of myrrh
    that lies all night between my breasts.
speaker: Narrator

text:
My beloved is to me a cluster of henna blossoms
    in the vineyards of En Gedi.
speaker: Narrator

text:
How fair you are, my love.
    How fair you are! Your eyes are doves.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
the beams of our house are cedar,
    and our rafters of fir.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I am the rose of Sharon,
    the lily of the valleys.
speaker: Narrator

text:
As a lily among thorns,
    so is my love among the maidens.
speaker: Narrator

text:
As an apple tree among the trees of the forest,
    so is my beloved among the young men.
In his shadow I sat with great delight,
    and his fruit was sweet to my taste.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He brought me to the banquet house,
    and his banner over me was love.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
His left hand is under my head,
    and his right hand embraces me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I charge you, O daughters of Jerusalem,
    by the gazelles or the does of the field,
do not stir up or awaken love
    until it pleases.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The voice of my beloved!
    Look, he comes
leaping over the mountains,
    bounding over the hills.
speaker: Narrator

text:
My beloved is like a gazelle or a young stag.
    Look, he stands behind our wall, gazing through the windows,
    looking through the lattice.
speaker: Narrator

text:
My beloved speaks and says to me:
    “Rise up, my love,
    my fair one, and come away.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For now the winter has past;
    the rain is over and gone.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
The fig tree puts forth its green figs,
    and the vines their blossoms;
and they give forth fragrance.
    Rise up, my love, my beautiful one, and come away.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
Catch the foxes for us,
    the little foxes
that spoil the vineyards,
    for our vineyards are in blossom.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
My beloved is mine, and I am his;
    he feeds his flock among the lilies.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Until the day breathes
    and the shadows flee,
turn, my beloved,
    be like a gazelle
or a young stag
    on the cleft mountains.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
I will rise now and go about the city,
    in the streets and in the squares;
I will seek him whom my soul loves.
    I sought him, but found him not.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The watchmen found me,
    as they went about the city.
    “Have you seen him whom my soul loves?”
speaker: Narrator

text:
Scarcely had I passed them,
    when I found him whom my soul loves.
I held him, and would not let him go
    until I brought him to my mother’s house,
    and into the chamber of her who conceived me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I charge you, O daughters of Jerusalem,
    by the gazelles or does of the field,
do not stir up or awaken love
    until it pleases.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Who is that coming up from the wilderness,
    like columns of smoke,
perfumed with myrrh and frankincense,
    with all the fragrant powders of the merchant?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Look, it is the litter of Solomon!
    Around it are sixty mighty men,
    of the mighty men of Israel,
speaker: Narrator

text:
all of them holding swords
    and expert in war,
each with his sword at his thigh,
    because of terrors by night.
speaker: Narrator

text:
King Solomon made himself a palanquin
    from the wood of Lebanon.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He made its posts of silver,
    its back of gold,
its seat of purple;
    its interior was inlaid with love
    by the daughters of Jerusalem.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Go forth, O daughters of Zion,
    and see King Solomon with the crown
    with which his mother crowned him
on the day of his wedding,
    on the day of the gladness of his heart.
speaker: Narrator

text:
How fair you are, my love!
    How very fair!
    Your eyes are doves behind your veil.
Your hair is like a flock of goats,
    streaming down the hills of Gilead.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Your teeth are like a flock of shorn ewes
    that have come up from the washing,
all of which bear twins,
    and not one among them has lost its young.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Your lips are like a scarlet thread,
    and your mouth is lovely.
Your cheeks are halves of a pomegranate
    behind your veil.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Your neck is like the tower of David,
    built in rows of stone;
on it hang a thousand shields,
    all of them shields of mighty men.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Your two breasts are like two fawns,
    twins of a gazelle,
    that feed among the lilies.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Until the day breathes
    and the shadows flee,
I will go away to the mountain of myrrh
    and the hill of frankincense.
speaker: Narrator

text:
You are altogether fair, my love;
    there is no flaw in you.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
You have ravished my heart, my sister, my bride;
    you have ravished my heart
with one glance of your eyes,
    with one jewel of your necklace.
speaker: Narrator

text:
How fair is your love, my sister, my bride!
    How much better than wine is your love,
    and the fragrance of your oils than any spice!
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
A garden locked is my sister, my bride,
    a fountain sealed.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Your plants are an orchard of pomegranates
    with all choicest fruits,
    henna with nard,
speaker: Narrator

text:
nard and saffron,
    calamus and cinnamon,
    with all trees of frankincense,
    myrrh and aloes,
    with all the chief spices—
speaker: Narrator

text:
a garden fountain,
    a well of living water,
    and flowing streams from Lebanon.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Awake, O north wind,
    and come, O south wind!
Blow upon my garden,
    that its spices may flow out.
Let my beloved come to his garden,
    and eat its choicest fruits.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator
Narrator
Narrator

text:
My beloved put his hand by the latch,
    and my heart yearned for him.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I rose up to open to my beloved,
    and my hands dripped with myrrh,
my fingers with liquid myrrh
    on the handles of the bolt.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I opened to my beloved,
    but my beloved had turned and was gone.
    My soul failed me when he spoke.
I sought him, but found him not;
    I called him, but he gave no answer.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator
Narrator

text:
What is your beloved more than another beloved,
    O fairest among women?
What is your beloved more than another beloved,
    that you so charge us?
speaker: Narrator

text:
My beloved is white and ruddy,
    distinguished among ten thousand.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
His eyes are like doves
    beside rivers of water,
bathed in milk,
    fitly set.
speaker: Narrator

text:
His cheeks are like beds of spices,
    mounds of scented herbs.
His lips are lilies,
    dripping liquid myrrh.
speaker: Narrator

text:
His arms are rods of gold,
    set with jewels.
His body is bright ivory,
    inlaid with sapphires.
speaker: Narrator

text:
His legs are alabaster columns,
    set on bases of gold.
His appearance is like Lebanon,
    choice as the cedars.
speaker: Narrator

text:
His mouth is most sweet,
    and he is altogether desirable.
This is my beloved and this is my friend,
    O daughters of Jerusalem.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Where has your beloved gone,
    O fairest among women?
Where has your beloved turned aside,
    that we may seek him with you?
speaker: Narrator

text:
My beloved has gone down to his garden,
    to the beds of spices,
to feed his flock in the gardens,
    and to gather lilies.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I am my beloved’s and my beloved is mine;
    he feeds his flock among the lilies.
speaker: Narrator

text:
You are beautiful as Tirzah, my love,
    comely as Jerusalem,
    awesome as an army with banners!
speaker: Narrator

text:
Turn your eyes away from me,
    for they overwhelm me!
Your hair is like a flock of goats
    streaming down from Gilead.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
your cheeks are like halves
    of a pomegranate behind your veil.
speaker: Narrator

text:
There are sixty queens
    and eighty concubines,
    and virgins without number.
speaker: Narrator

text:
My dove, my perfect one, is the only one,
    the only one of her mother,
    choice to her who bore her.
The maidens saw her and called her blessed;
    the queens and concubines also, and they praised her.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Who is this who looks forth like the dawn,
    fair as the moon, radiant as the sun,
    awesome as an army with banners?
speaker: Narrator

text:
I went down to the nut orchard
    to look at the blossoms of the valley,
to see whether the vines had budded,
    whether the pomegranates were in bloom.
speaker: Narrator

text: Before I was aware, my soul set me in a chariot beside my prince.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Return, return, O Shulammite!
    Return, return, that we may look upon you.
Why should you look upon the Shulammite,
    as upon a dance before two armies?
speaker: Narrator

text:
How beautiful are your feet in sandals,
    O prince’s daughter!
The curves of your thighs are like jewels,
    the work of a master hand.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Your navel is a round bowl
    that never lacks mixed wine.
Your belly is a heap of wheat,
    encircled with lilies.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Your two breasts are like two fawns,
    twins of a gazelle.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Your neck is like an ivory tower,
    your eyes pools in Heshbon,
    by the gate of Bath Rabbim.
Your nose is like a tower of Lebanon,
    overlooking Damascus.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
How fair and pleasant you are,
    O loved one, with all your delights!
speaker: Narrator

text:
Your stature is like a palm tree,
    and your breasts are like its clusters.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I say I will climb the palm tree
    and take hold of its branches.
Oh, may your breasts be like clusters of the vine,
    and the scent of your breath like apples,
speaker: Narrator

text:
and your mouth like the best wine.
It goes down smoothly for my beloved,
    gliding over lips and teeth.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I am my beloved’s,
    and his desire is for me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Come, my beloved, let us go forth into the fields,
    and lodge in the villages;
speaker: Narrator

text:
let us go out early to the vineyards,
    and see whether the vines have budded,
whether the grape blossoms have opened
    and the pomegranates are in bloom.
    There I will give you my love.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The mandrakes give forth fragrance,
    and at our doors are all choice fruits,
new as well as old,
    which I have laid up for you, my beloved.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Oh, that you were like a brother to me,
    who nursed at my mother’s breasts!
If I found you outside,
    I would kiss you,
    and no one would despise me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I would lead you and bring you
    into the house of my mother,
    she who used to instruct me.
I would give you spiced wine to drink,
    the juice of my pomegranates.
speaker: Narrator

text:
His left hand is under my head,
    and his right arm embraces me!
speaker: Narrator

text:
I charge you, O daughters of Jerusalem,
    do not stir up or awaken love
    until it pleases.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Who is that coming up from the wilderness,
    leaning upon her beloved?
Under the apple tree I awakened you.
    There your mother was in labor with you;
    there she who bore you was in labor.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
Many waters cannot quench love,
    neither can floods drown it.
If a man offered for love
    all the wealth of his house,
    it would be utterly condemned.
speaker: Narrator

text:
We have a little sister,
    and she has no breasts.
What will we do for our sister
    on the day when she is spoken for?
speaker: Narrator

text:
If she is a wall,
    we will build upon her a battlement of silver;
but if she is a door,
    we will enclose her with boards of cedar.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I was a wall,
    and my breasts were like towers;
then I was in his eyes
    as one who finds peace.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator
Narrator
Narrator

text:
Make haste, my beloved,
    and be like a gazelle or a young stag
    on the mountains of spices!
speaker: Narrator
